Example including vega-lite

There are two plots. Both of them together. One plot is a bar chart, where you can select what type of buildings you want to focus on. You can select multiple. I have set the x axis and y axis title accordingly, however I have found default color scheme to be fine. Alternatively, I could go with a traffic light approach where Red is abandoned, Yellow is in progress and Green is In Use. It has a standard x and y encoding of x as the type of building status while y is the count. A colormap is not necessary for this as it is 2 dimensional data. The axis is symmetric log, as not many buildings are in-construction or abandoned so to signifize their existence, we have used log. It also shows there are exponentially higher in use buildings.

The other graph is interactive and its intent is to give you a map view of where buildings are concentrated, whilst the first one gives an idea of the total distribution of buildings. The tooltip gives useful information like how many buildings are there, what zip code and coordinates of the zip code. The interaction comes from the first graph where the user selects which types of buildings distribution they want to see on the map. I have used size encoding as that allows good focus. Initially I tried to use zip code region boundaries and colors but zipcodes are too small that it is not as effective. For example 61820 has a lot of buildings but is small. We didn't need to add color here, as the user can control the information they need to see by themselves. An improvement which would have taken more time is to have red, yellow, green again for each dots and a total view as blue and the user toggles if they want total view (which they adjust by selection) or the color dots view (they can turn colors on and off).

The main transformations for these datasets was combining the dataset from altair-vegalite and the data we have and aggregating based on zipcodes and applying an inner join. Inner join was applied because we didn't have coordinates of some zip codes and they have been excluded from this graph. We (Singular) also filtered the zipcodes to only Illinois to keep the focus region small and digestable.
